title: Markdown Guide
body:
Markdown allows you to format text using a very simple syntax. The Markdown formatted text is only converted to HTML once it's necessary to display it. Below is a quick guide to using Markdown to create your content.

**Note: pay attention to the single space between opening symbols (e.g. \*,\#) and text.**

## Headers
# h1â€“h6
```
# h1
## h2
### h3
#### h4
##### h5
###### h6
```
# h1
## h2
### h3
#### h4
##### h5
###### h6

## Emphasis
#### _italics_
`_italics_ or *italics*`

#### **Bold**
`**bold**`

## Links
```
[My special link](/content/markdown/ "Hover text")
```
[My special link](/content/markdown/ "Hover text")

Or...

```
[My tidy link][1]
...some content and then...
[1]: /content/markdown/
```
[My tidy link][1]

## Images
```
!["Alt text"](/gin-data/themes/gin-whitepaper/img/gin.png "Hover text")
```
!["Alt text"](/gin-data/themes/gin-whitepaper/img/gin.png "Hover text")

Or...
```
!["Alt text"][gin]
...
[gin]: /gin-data/themes/gin-whitepaper/img/gin.png "Hover text"
```
!["Alt text"][gin]
[gin]: /gin-data/themes/gin-whitepaper/img/gin.png "Hover text"

## Lists
#### Numbered lists
````
* item a
* item b
* item c
```

#### Unordered lists
```
1. item
2. item
3. item
```

[1]: /content/markdown/
